setup.question: What best describes how the overall tone changed from the beginning of the article?

Text.text: Both seem equally plausible.
its definitely lighthearted in the beginning:
the story changes beat here:

this is the center to the plot - Eddie's dad works as a scientist testing on uranium atoms in relation to nuclear power it seems. the special isoptope they are waiting on is stolen by someone who had knowledge about the shipment.

the story becomes tense due to this robbery:
pre-empting sympathy stuff - theres admittedly some sympathy offered from the characters to each other but its not the tone of the story

Story is about Eddie a big science nerd. His dad, atomic scientist at a college, has order of new radioisotope coming in. However, shipment was stolen in middle of the story.

The entire story is through the perspective of Eddie, a kid, and the tone never gets to anything tense. He never sees the theft firsthand, everything we get told via conversations, his dad was concerned but seemed pretty chill about it. Ending is a convo between him and his friend's mom who he visits after dinner. He explains what radioisotopes are.

Upbeat:
Sympathy

Weakly updating in favor of A.

A, why is sympathy not the tone of the story? Also, B claims that "the tone never gets to anything tense". Can you spend some quotes just citing the broader context of your "tense" examples?
B: You provide only a single quote at the very end for "sympathetic" and a few very-close-together quotes for "upbeat" from the very beginning. Do you have more support for these tones throughout the story? Also, what exactly does "sympathetic" mean as a tone?

Your question Judge about what makes sympathethic a tone is why I object to it and believe I am honest - its not really a tone and outside of a few times one character (Teena's mom) is nice to other characters its not really a reoccuring issue. but tension matters - Eddie's dad's work has grave implications if it gets into the wrong hands:
also while the story doesn't explain the below quote much since it gets cut off one of the last lines ever is this one:

.
seems theres a lot of tension

I think Judge, the most important aspect is what Eddie feels. He is the main character of the story and everything is told through his pov. 90% of story is conversations between eddie and dif characters, including Eddie learning about theft; the only moment that could amount to tense.
Eddie is def concerned but there's a sense that he can't do anything to help since he's just a kid; sympathetic fits much more.
The entire ending is a convo where Teena, her mom ask questions about radioisotopes to Eddie.

A: Can you provide more evidence for "lighthearted"? Right now you only have Mr. Taylor being polite.

B: A has provided some ev that points to discussions of stereotypically "tense" things (explosions, theft, etc). Can you provide an account for why this shouldn't be seen as "tense"? Also, I'm still not super clear what you mean by "what Eddie feels". Is this your arg for what it means to be "sympathetic"? If so, does the story not talk about his feelings earlier on? If not, what does it mean to have a "sympathetic" tone?
idk what the distinction between lighthearted and upbeat is but theres certainly more ev:

I really do. [ran out of quote ev to make those last two words work]

more tension ev:

- feels like this probably can end the round
b has no evidence that is as blatant as that line

lastly - sympathethic tone just isn't really a thing - characters being sympathethic =/ prove that the tone is sympathethic because its mostly just one character, Teena's mom who isnt the main character.

Sympathetic as in what Eddie thinks and does in his current situation. 

1. 4944-4965: Eddie sympathizes with his father's sit and finds someone else to talk to.
2.Eddie's internal thoughts upon meeting Teena's mom and what he says seeing that she wasn't as cheerful as usual:
3. All quotes A provided are in the context of Eddie explaining radioisotopes to Teena and Mom:
A chose small quotes discussing what radioisotopes are capable of but the overall tone is calm.

I agree that there isn't really a strong distinction between A's "lighthearted" and B's "upbeat". Either debater's evidence for the early part of the story works for the other on this. The disagreement then is about "tense" vs "sympathetic".

I buy A's argument more. B, you didn't really respond to my question about why A's "tense" ev should be discounted.

I think it's A's ev is better so far, but I'd like to see more ev from the parts of the story we haven't seen cited yet. If you both agree that the tonal change happens around 2935, we can stick to after than point.

A, how do you respond to B's claims about the tone being "calm".  And can you expand a bit about the debate about the isotopes?
B: again, why discount the "tense" ev?
heres some contextual ev right when the story turns:

. this stuff sounds stressful and tense - i don't think you can interpret much here that feels sympathethic.


if the tone is 'calm' id say it flows A - B implies that things are fast paced (upbeat --> sympathethic) where as my argument doesn't. it says things are chill in the beginning and not chill at all in the end.

i continue to ask both you the judge and B what it means to have a sympathethic tone because i don't think thats really a easy to write tone. eddie is nice to ppl sure but that doesnt make the tone un-tense.

Tone is not tense because it is a conversation between Eddie and his friend and mom. They are not in any threat, in fact they don't even know what radioisotope is: 5345. I can't see how the tone of this convo can be tense at all given a)its convo between friends b)one of the parties don't even know what the dangers are. 
ex. imagine having u having a convo with a friend about AI and you have no idea what the dangers they pose. This is hardly a tense atmosphere.
mom and teena crack a joke here:

A, how do you respond to B's points about the tone seeming happy in the last bit of the story?
B, can you fill in the gaps on those quotes? Just so they're less scattered.

The 'not any threat' thing B says is a straight up lie. Did we forget the evidence I quoted about the potential of these uranium isotopes to lead to the development atomic bomb? And especially  in the wrong hands? 
B provides some evidence that not all the characters are depressed sure but this doesn't deduct from the tone being tense. 
1. i still have out-right ev that beats everything B has - look back on 6737-6775 --> serious and tense are synonmous especially within this context.
2. B's 'happyiness' =/ sympathethic lol there is a super weak correlation here
3. this part of the story B is using is still tense:

The truth is the people who aren't familiar with radioisotopes don't seem to be too worried about the stolen shipment. Just doing a lil guesswork: but story ends halfway and given title it seems like Eddie sympathetic about Dad goes out to look for stolen radioiso

A cut a lotta quotes here, sus: Mr. Ross makes a joke before saying he's not feeling particularly good:

to which Eddie responds sympathetically: 7467-7478 very last line of the story 

Sure I can fill in the gaps:
eddie continues joke:

A, what do you have to say about B's claim that the other characters don't seem to know much about isotopes and so aren't that troubled by it? (e.g., 7096)
B, even if some characters don't know about them, some clearly do, so why wouldn't that infuence tenseness? Also, can you fill in the quotes on 7257–7294 and the bit about Mr Ross not feeling good?

B is right to an extent - before Eddie informs then Teena and Teena's mom don't get it. But teena's mom (Ms. Ross) from 6737-6775 (as i quoted earlier) does get that its serious. And more importantly Eddie, his dad, his mom and the writer all seem to get it from the getgo. This is all information from when Eddie's dad tells Eddie about the robbery:
. This stuff screams concern, threat and tension - Ms. Ross doesn't even offer sympathy to Mr. Taylor in this entire story - the guy whos actually concerned.

I'm not saying it doesn't get serious. But serious can turn into sympathy or tense. Sympathy is shown when serious happens. And because Eddie is never involved the stolen shipment, tasked with any mission about it, the best he can and does offer is sympathy to others. Teena and mom get that its serious but they are still in a good mood, they don't think anything bad will happen=requisite for tension. 

Eddie is clearly the focus of the story, look at ev at the beginning for upbeat: it all talks about how Eddie is feeling, we never get internal thoughts of any other characters. 

Ev from A is a convo between son and dad.
a lot of q&a ev i can give
Resolving for A. I think that there's more evidence to support "tense" than "sympathetic", although I'm not super confidence in this decision.

answers.reason for outcome: Honest had better ev and a more coherent story.
honest and sympathethic is not an easy to read or easy to write tone.
